speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would like to start by noting that it has been a full year since the pandemic arrived with force on our shores.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking back, it was clear that addressing a fast-moving global pandemic would be plainly and primarily the realm of health-care providers and experts, and we are grateful to them and to all the essential workers for their service and sacrifice.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The danger to the U.S. economy was also clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Congress provided by far the fastest and largest response to any postwar economic downturn, offering fiscal support for households, businesses, health-care providers, and state and local governments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Here at the Federal Reserve, we rapidly deployed our full range of tools to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic fallout has been real and widespread, but with the benefit of perspective, we can say that some of the very worst economic outcomes have been avoided by swift and forceful action—from Congress, from across government, and in cities and towns across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More people held on to their jobs, more businesses kept their doors open, and more incomes were saved as a result of these swift and forceful policy actions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And while we welcome these positive developments, no one should be complacent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Fed, we will continue to provide the economy the support that it needs for as long as it takes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today the FOMC kept interest rates near zero and maintained our sizable asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and on our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The path of the economy continues to depend significantly on the course of the virus and the measures undertaken to control its spread.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since January, the number of new cases, hospitalizations, and deaths has fallen, and ongoing vaccinations offer hope for a return to more normal conditions later this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In the meantime, continued observance of social-distancing measures and wearing masks will help us reach that goal as soon as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic recovery remains uneven and far from complete, and the path ahead remains uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Following the moderation in the pace of the recovery that began toward the end of last year, indicators of economic activity and employment have turned up recently, although the sectors of the economy most adversely affected by the resurgence of the virus and by greater social distancing remain weak.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending on goods has risen notably so far this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In contrast, household spending on services remains low, especially in services that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The housing sector has more than fully recovered from the downturn, while business investment and manufacturing production have also picked up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The overall recovery in economic activity since last spring is due importantly to unprecedented fiscal and monetary policy actions, which have provided essential support to households, businesses, and communities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected, and forecasts from FOMC participants for economic growth this year have been revised up notably since our December Summary of Economic Projections.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In commenting on the stronger outlook, participants noted progress on vaccinations as well as recent fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, conditions in the labor market have turned up recently.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Employment rose by 379,000 in February, as the leisure and hospitality sector recouped about March 17, 2021 two-thirds of the jobs that were lost in December and January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, employment in this Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL sector is more than 3 million below its level at the onset of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For the economy as a whole, employment is 9.5 million below its pre-pandemic level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate remains elevated at 6.2 percent in February; this figure understates the shortfall in employment, particularly as participation in the labor market remains notably below pre-pandemic levels.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, FOMC participants project the unemployment rate to continue to decline; the median projection is 4.5 percent at the end of this year and moves down to 3.5 percent by the end of 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been the hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the service sector and for African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Over the next few months, 12-month measures of inflation will move up as the very low readings from March and April of last year fall out of the calculation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Beyond these base effects, we could also see upward pressure on prices if spending rebounds quickly as the economy continues to reopen, particularly if supply bottlenecks limit how quickly production can respond in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: However, these one-time increases in prices are likely to have only transient effects on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median inflation projection of FOMC participants is 2.4 percent this year and declines to 2 percent next year before moving back up by the end of 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the financial—the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As we say in our Statement on March 17, 2021 Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we view maximum employment as a “broad-Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL based and inclusive goal.” Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the Committee reiterated in today’s policy statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would note that a transitory rise in inflation above 2 percent, as seems likely to occur this year, would not meet this standard.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage-backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The increase in our balance sheet since last March has materially eased financial conditions and is providing substantial support to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy is a long way from our employment and inflation goals, and it is likely to take some time for substantial further progress to be achieved.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our forward guidance for the federal funds rate, along with our balance sheet guidance, will ensure that the stance of monetary policy remains highly accommodative as the recovery progresses.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our guidance is outcome based and ties the path of the federal funds rate and the March 17, 2021 balance sheet to progress toward reaching our employment and inflation goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Overall, our Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I look forward to your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: [Laughter] Not yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you—as you pointed out, we’ve said that we would continue asset purchases at this pace until we see substantial further progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s actual progress, not forecast progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and that’s a difference from, from our past approach.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—and what we mean by that is, is pretty straightforward.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is, we want to see that, that the labor markets have moved—labor market conditions have moved—you know, have made substantial progress toward maximum employment, and inflation has made substantial progress toward the 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’re going to want to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, that obviously includes an element of judgment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And when we see—we’ll be—we’ll be carefully looking ahead.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we also understand that we, we will want to provide as much advance notice of any potential taper as possible.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So when we see that we’re on track, when we see actual data coming in that suggests that we’re on track to perhaps achieve substantial further progress, then we’ll say so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll say so well in advance of any decision to actually taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I don’t see that at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we, we have a, a range of perspectives on the Committee.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we have—we debate things, we discuss things, and we always come together around a—around a, a solution.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, the, the strong bulk of the Committee is, is not showing a rate increase during this forecast period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, as, as data improve, as the outlook improves very significantly since the December meeting, you would expect forecasts to move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s probably not a surprise that some people would bring in their estimate of the appropriate time for liftoff.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Nonetheless, you know, the bulk of the Committee—the, the largest part by far of the Committee is, is—doesn’t show a rate increase during this period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, part of that is wanting to see actual data rather than just a forecast at this point.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We do expect that we’ll begin to make faster progress on both spending—you know, labor markets and inflation as the year goes on because of the progress with the vaccines, because of the fiscal support that we’re getting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We expect that to happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, we’ll have to see it first.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Victoria, we’ll have something to announce on that in coming days.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’m not going to expound upon your questions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Because, because that one—I’m just going to say that we’ll have something in coming days.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, let me say, as we say in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we look to a range of indicators on the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We never only looked at the unemployment rate, which is the only indicator of, of labor market outcomes that’s in the SEP. We look at a very broad range.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You hear us talk all the time about participation; about employment to population, which is the combination of the two; about different measures of, of unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s wages, it’s, it’s the job flows, it’s, you know, all of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They go into an assessment—disparities of various groups.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: All that goes into an assessment of maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The, the—trying to incorporate all of that into the Summary of Economic Projections would not be practical.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, obviously, the thing that we do include is just the unemployment rate, and that’s a very insufficient statistic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—it, it doesn’t include a lot of other things that we—that we do look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I wouldn’t want to say that we’re looking to include the other dozen things that we look at into the SEP.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But at time—from time to time, we do look at, at adding different things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I, I would just say the SEP is, it’s a summary.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s one device.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not going to include all of the things that we look at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think you know the things that we look at—we, we talk about them all the time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re not actually looking actively at significantly broadening those indicators in the SEP right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I guess the first thing to say is that the, the SEP is not a Committee forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s not something we sit around and debate and discuss and approve, and say, “This represents our, you know, our reaction function as a Committee.” It’s a compilation of projections from different people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I—since we don’t debate it or discuss it, it would be hard for me to say why—exactly why each participant did what they were going to do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all I would say about this is that we’ve—we laid out what I think is very clear guidance on liftoff.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s really three things: labor market conditions that are consistent with our estimates of maximum employment—and, as I mentioned, we consider a wide range of indicators in assessing labor market conditions, not just the unemployment rate; inflation that has reached 2 percent, and not just on a transitory basis; and inflation that’s on track to run moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The first two of those three are very much data based; the third does have a little bit of a—of an element of expectations in it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we are very much determined to implement this guidance in a robust way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It is the guidance that we chose carefully to implement our new framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And to meet these standards, we’ll need to see data, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It says that we’re committed to our framework and to the guidance we’ve provided to implement that framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will wait until the requirements set forth in that guidance are clearly met before considering a change in our policy rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the last thing I’ll say is this: The state of the economy in two or three years is highly uncertain, and I wouldn’t want to focus too much on the exact timing of a potential rate increase that far into the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I would think about the, the SEP. MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Paul Kiernan.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve said we’d like to see inflation run moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ve resisted, basically, generally, the temptation to try to quantify that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of that just is, talking about inflation is one thing; actually having inflation run above 2 percent is the real thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—you know, over the years we’ve, we’ve talked about 2 percent inflation as a goal, but we haven’t achieved it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I, I would say we’d like to, you know, perform.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s what we’d really like to do, is to get inflation moderately above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t want to be too specific about what that means, because I think it’s hard to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we haven’t done it yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, when we’re actually above 2 percent, we can do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I—look, I, I would say this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The fundamental change in, in our framework is that we, we’re not going to act preemptively based on forecasts for the most part.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re going to wait to see actual data.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it will take people time to, to adjust to that—and to adjust to that new practice.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the only way we can really build the credibility of that is by doing it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I would think about that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, on, on herd immunity, I, I’m really going to leave that question to the experts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t control that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re not responsible for defining it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’ll, we’ll leave that whole discussion to the experts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, we’re—what we’re focused on is, is the part that we control, which is the support that we provide to the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And there we’ve provided very clear guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in the case of asset purchases, it’s at their current level until we make substantial further progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is an element of judgment in that, and we’ll, we’ll—therefore, we’ll supply clear communication well in advance of, of actually tapering, and we just went through, you know, the, the criteria for raising interest rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re very specific.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we’re, we’re very much committed to having them fulfilled robustly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I would agree with you that the, the path of the virus continues to be very important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we have these, you know, new strains with—which, which can be quite virulent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not actually done yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I, I—we’re clearly on a good path with, with cases coming down, as I mentioned, but we’re not done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’d hate to see us take our eye off the ball before we actually finish the job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s how I would look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s some of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure, there’ll be some of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There will still be some social distancing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People may be, for example, going into spaces that, that, you know, that involve close contact with others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Some people will do that right away.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Others will hold back.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so I think there’ll—there’ll be some of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In addition, though, remember, there are—there are 10 million people—in the range of 10 million people who need to get back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s going to take some time for that to happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, it can—it can happen maybe, maybe more quickly than it has in the past, because it involves the reopening of a sector of the economy, as opposed to stimulating aggregate demand and waiting for that to produce job demand for workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This could be a different sort of a process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it could be quicker.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t know that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s, it’s just a lot of people who have—who need to get back to work.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s not going to happen overnight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would be—it’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: No matter how well the economy performs, unemployment will take quite a time to go—to go down, and so will participation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s all I can say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the faster the better; we’d love to see it come sooner rather than later.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’d welcome nothing more than that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, realistically, given the numbers, it’s going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we monitor a broad range of financial conditions, and we’re always attentive to market developments, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re still a long way from our goals, and it’s important that financial conditions do remain accommodative to support the achievement of those goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if you look at various indexes of financial conditions, what you’ll see is that they generally do show financial conditions overall to be highly accommodative.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s how we look at it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I would add, as I’ve said, I would be concerned by disorderly conditions in markets or by a persistent tightening of financial conditions that threaten the achievement of our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think the stance of our—of monetary policy remains appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our guidance on the federal funds rate and on asset purchases is providing strong support for the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re committed to maintaining that patiently accommodative stance until the job is well and truly done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we—the tools we have are the tools we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What I’m telling you is that the stance of monetary policy we have today, we believe, is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think that our asset purchases in their current form—which is to say, you know, across the curve, $80 billion in Treasuries, $40 billion in mortgage-backed securities on net—we think that that’s, that’s the right place for our asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, we can—we can change them, of course, in, in a number of different dimensions should we deem that that’s appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, for now, we think that our policy stance on that is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, which measures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we, we do monitor and communicate very regularly about different labor market—disparities in the labor market, let’s say.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the African American unemployment rate is substantially elevated, and so is the Hispanic unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we look at those and we see those as, you know—it’s, it’s slack in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, it’s sad to see, because those disparities had really come down to record lows since we started keeping the data that way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As recently as a year ago, February of last year, we had those, those disparities quite low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What happens in a downturn, though, is they move up at twice the speed of white unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we monitor those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—our tools, of course, affect unemployment generally, but we’re going to look at those as, as a form of slack in the labor market and hope that, you know, that there’s progress there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and this particular downturn, of course, was just a direct hit on, on a part of the economy that employs many minorities and lower-paid workers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The public-facing workers in the service industries in many cases don’t have a lot of financial assets, they’re not tremendously well paid, they might have other jobs, and things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this was a direct hit on that part of March 17, 2021 the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s the slowest part of the economy to recover.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, we’d like to Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL see those people continue to get supported, you know, as we—as the broader economy recovers, which, which it’s very much doing now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of disparate levels of vaccination, that’s—those are facts and unfortunate facts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re really not something we, we have within our policy toolkit to address.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it is—it is true, though, that the data we have suggests that there are—there are significant disparities between different ethnic groups and—you know, but that’s, that’s not for us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s for fiscal authorities and the government more generally to, to work on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I do think that fiscal policy overall will have really helped us to avoid much of the scarring that we were very, very concerned about at the beginning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think that’s just the size and the speed with which Congress has delivered—you know, with the CARES Act and since then, has—is going to wind up very much accelerating the return to full employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s going to make a huge difference in people’s lives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it has already.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned in my remarks—opening remarks, the recovery has been faster than we expected.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of that just is, it’s very hard to predict, given we’ve never seen an event like this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But part of it is just the strength of the fiscal response, which I think will, will look good over the March 17, 2021 years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Longer term, you know, to, to really—that’s—the first part of it is about avoiding Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL scarring, and I think we’ve not avoided all of the scarring, but we’ve probably avoided the worst cases there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and I hope we keep at it, and we will keep at it with our policies, of course, to do whatever we can to make sure that’s—that continues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Longer term though, what it takes to drive productive capacity per capita or per hour worked, to raise living standards over time, is investment: investment in people’s skills and aptitudes, investment in plant and equipment, investment in software.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It takes a lot of investment to, to support a more productive economy and raise living standards.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s—you know, that hasn’t been the principal focus with these measures—our measures, certainly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we don’t have those tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But what Congress has been doing has mainly been replacing lost income and beginning to, you know, support people as the economy returns to normal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there should be a focus on—a longer-term focus, I think, would be healthy on, on the investment front.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right that the pace of the recovery is that we’re having diverging recoveries here, as we did after the last crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in this case, as well as the other one, the U.S.’s recovery is, is leading the global recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we conduct policy, March 17, 2021 of course, here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our, our focus is on—our, you know—our, our objectives are domestic ones.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL It’s, it’s maximum employment and price stability here in the United States.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We monitor developments abroad, and we know—because they know we know that they can—those can affect our outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think U.S. demand—very strong U.S. demand, if, if—as the economy improves is going to support global activity as well over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That, that’ll be through imports.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, when the U.S. economy is strong, that strength tends to be—tends to support global, global activity as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t—I don’t worry in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I’d love to see Europe growing faster.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’d love to see the vaccine rollout going more smoothly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I don’t worry too much about us in the near term, because we’re, we’re on a very good track.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Very strong fiscal support coming, now vaccination going quickly, and cases coming down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’re—I think we’re in a good place.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s all ahead of us, but the data should, should get stronger fairly quickly here and remain strong for some time here.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we haven’t made a decision on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re a couple weeks away from announcing that decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I won’t foreshadow it here today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I will say, we’re going to continue our data-driven approach.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know that we restricted buybacks and dividends, so the firms are preserving capital.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Through 2020, the banks actually increased their level of capital March 17, 2021 and their level of reserves.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the December stress tests showed that banks are strong and well Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL capitalized under our hypothetical recessions that we—that we used in December, which were quite stringent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re right in the middle of our 2021 stress tests, and we’ll release those results before the end of June.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that layers, you know, very significant additional stress on top of the stress the banks have already absorbed over the past year, with the unemployment rate going to 11 percent and stock prices falling more than 50 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but all of that, you know, the results of the stress tests and the decision on distributions—all of that is to come fairly soon, as I mentioned.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you know, it all depends.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve set out very clear criteria for liftoff, right, where we’ve said we want to see labor market conditions that are consistent with our estimates of, of maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that doesn’t just mean unemployment, it means a much broader set of criteria.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want inflation at 2 percent, and not on a transitory basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we want inflation on track to be moderately—to run moderately above 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those are the three conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you want to—if you want to—you know, people will have a range of, of assessments for how good the economy is March 17, 2021 going to be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we, we don’t—I would say that we’re in a relatively highly Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL uncertain situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the uncertainty, people, people on the Committee broadly say that uncertainty about the forecast is, is very high compared to the normal level.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t come out of a pandemic before.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We haven’t had this kind of fiscal support before, totaling it all up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re going to have different perspectives from Committee participants about how fast growth will be, how fast the labor market will heal, or how fast—sorry, inflation will move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s an estimate based on—based on assumptions about growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s, it’s meant to be a tool to generally show the public how, how our objective function works, how we think about the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t meant to actually pin down a time when we might or might not lift off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We—you know, we’re not going to make that decision for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The chances are that the economy in that time and place will be very different from the one we think it’ll be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I—sometimes with the dots, I have to be sure to point out that they—they’re not a Committee forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you know this, but it’s—they’re not a Committee forecast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just compiling these projections, really, of individual people.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We think it serves a useful purpose.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not meant to, to actually be a promise or even a prediction of when the Committee will act.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That will be very much dependent on economic outcomes, which are highly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, Brian, it’s not up to us to decide what, what Congress should spend money on or when.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think what’s happened so far has done a pretty good job of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, really, I wanted to make the longer-run point that if—to work on the productivity—on productivity over longer periods, that is—that is—comes down to a number of things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But one of those things is investment: investment in people, in their skills, education, aptitude, all of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not in any way suggesting that that’s something Congress should work on right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Or that, you know, that’s just not my—that’s not our job.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m just saying, that, that is what fiscal policy can do that, really, monetary policy can’t do—is, is invest in the future productive capacity of the economy, raise potential growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those things are completely tools that Congress has.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, I wasn’t making a comment at all on the current fiscal setting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you know, financial stability for us is, is a framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not a particular market or a particular asset or anything like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a March 17, 2021 framework that we, we have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We report on it semiannually, the Board gets a report on it Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL quarterly, and we monitor every day.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it has—it has four pillars, and those are four key vulnerabilities: asset valuations, debt owed by businesses and households, funding risk, and leverage among financial institutions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Those four things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I’ll just quickly touch on them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at asset valuations, you can say that by some measures, some asset valuations are elevated compared to history.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think that’s clear.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of households and businesses, households entered the, the crisis in very good shape by historical standards.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Leverage in the household sector had been just kind of gradually moving down and down and down since the—since the financial crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Now, there was—there was some negative effects on that, people lost their jobs and that sort of thing, but they’ve also gotten a lot of support now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the damage hasn’t been as, as bad as we thought.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Businesses, by the same token, had a high debt load coming in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And—but—and many saw their revenues decline.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But there’s—they’ve done so much financing, and there’s a lot of cash on their balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So nothing in those two sectors really jumps out as really troubling.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Short term—I mentioned funding risk as the—as the last one.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we saw, again, in this crisis, breakdowns in parts of the short-term funding markets—came under a tremendous amount of stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And they’ve been quiet since the spring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we shut down our facilities and all of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we, we don’t—we don’t feel like we can let the moment pass without just saying again that we—that those—some aspects of the short-term funding markets and, more broadly, nonbank financial intermediation didn’t hold up so well under great stress—under tremendous stress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we need to go back and look at that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So a very high priority for us as regulators and supervisors is going to be to go back—and this, this will involve all the other regulatory agencies; it does involve all of them as well—and see if we can strengthen those March 17, 2021 things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s a—sort of a broader, detailed look.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I wouldn’t want to focus too much on the exact timing of a potential rate increase that far into the future.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what I would say is, we’re committed to giving the economy the support that it needs to return as quickly as possible to a state of maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, to the extent having rates low and support for monetary policy broadly, to the extent that raises other questions, we think it’s absolutely essential to maintain the strength and stability of the—of the broader financial system and to carefully monitor financial stability questions if that’s what you’re getting at.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we, we do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We will—we monitor them very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I, I would point out that, over the long expansion—the longest in U.S. history, 10 years and 8 months—rates were very low for—they were at zero for, you know, 7 years and then—and then never got above, you know, 2.4 percent, roughly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: During that, we didn’t see, actually, excess buildup of debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We didn’t see asset prices form into bubbles that would threaten the progress of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We didn’t see the things you—we didn’t see a housing bubble.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the things that have tended to really hurt an economy and have in recent history hurt the U.S., we didn’t see them build up despite very low rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Part of that just is that you’re in a low-rate environment, you’re in a much lower rate environment, and the connection between low March 17, 2021 rates and the kind of financial instability issues is just not as tight as people think it is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL That’s not to say we ignore it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t ignore it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we watch it very carefully.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, we found some other areas that need strengthening, and that’s what we’re working on now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I would say a couple things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There was a time when there was a tight connection between unemployment and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That time is long gone.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had extremely low unemployment in, in—not extremely low.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We had low unemployment in 2018 and ’19 and the beginning of ’20 without having troubling inflation at all.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were at 3.5 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were bouncing around with unemployment 3.5 percent to 4 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it wasn’t just unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participation was high, wages were moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was a very healthy thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we didn’t see price inflation move up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There is a relationship between wage inflation and unemployment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But that has not—what, what happens is that when wages move up because unemployment is low, companies have been absorbing that increase into their margins rather than raising prices.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that seems to be a feature of late-cycle behavior.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, we’re not—when, when we—when we seek to achieve low unemployment, high levels of employment, which is our mandate, you know, we think we have the freedom to do that based on the data without worrying too much about inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’ve said “substantial further progress.” Now, if you go back, October, November—sorry, November, December, and January, progress in the labor market slowed very sharply.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you had an average of 29,000 jobs per month.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you go back and look at the, the level of job creation before that, it was very, very high—very high.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we weren’t making any progress on the labor market from November through January.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: February, we saw a nice—a nice pickup, a good jobs report—379,465 private sector.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s good.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It can go so much higher, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, and, you know, it would be nice to see—to really make faster progress that’s different from substantial progress, we’d like to see it be, be higher than that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think it will be.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s—the expectation is, you’ll see now, I think, really strong job creation return—not as high as it was in the very early days of the recovery, the reopening of the economy, but, nonetheless, very strong.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So what, what I’m saying is, to achieve substantial progress from where we are, having had three months of, of very little progress, is going to take some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s—we don’t want to get into—I don’t want to get into trying to put a pin on the calendar someplace, because it’s going to be data dependent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: When we see—when we see ourselves on track to make substantial further progress, we’re going to—we’re going to say so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand fully that March 17, 2021 that test is one that involves judgment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL If you remember, during the Global Financial Crisis recovery, we said quantitative easing, number three, was—the test was a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, it means a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It meant we would communicate when we thought we had that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is just like that, in a way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: What we’re saying is, substantial further progress toward our goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll tell people when we think—until we—until we say—until we give a signal, you can assume we’re not there yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And as we approach it, well in advance—well in advance—we will give a signal that, yes, we’re on a path to, to possibly achieve that, to consider tapering.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s how we’re planning to handle it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s not different, really, from, from QE3.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’ve learned—what we’ve learned from the experience of these last dozen years is to communicate very carefully, very clearly, well in advance, and then follow through with, with your communications.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In this case, it’s, it’s an outcome-based set of guidance, as our rate guidance is, and it’s going to depend on the progress of the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s why it’s not appropriate to start pointing at dates yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We, you know, we and everyone who’s forecasting these—what, what we’re all doing is, we are looking at the—at the amount of savings.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re looking at—you March 17, 2021 know, we have reasonably good data on that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re looking at the government transfers Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL that’ll be made as part of the various laws.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re trying to make an assessment on what will be the tendency of people to spend that money, the marginal propensity to consume.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And from that, you can develop an estimate of the impact on spending, on growth, on hiring, and, ultimately, on inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, that’s what we’re all doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we have, you know, we have—we can look at history, and we can make estimates, and those are all very transparent and public.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you can compare one to the other.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, we’ve all—we’ve all done that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’ve made very conservative assumptions and sensible mainstream assumptions at each step of that process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And what, what it comes down to is what I said before, which is, there very likely will be a step-up in inflation as March and April of last year drop out of the 12-month window, because they were very low inflation numbers.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a—that’ll be a fairly significant pop in inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’ll wear off quickly, though, because it—just the way the numbers are calculated.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Past that, as the economy reopens, people will start spending more, and then, you know, you can only go out to dinner once per night, but a lot of people can go out to dinner.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so—and they’re not doing that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’re not going to restaurants, not going to theaters.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But as that happens, people can start to spend.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s also—wouldn’t be surprising if—and you’re seeing this now, particularly in the goods economy—there’ll be bottlenecks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They won’t be—they won’t be able to service all of the demand maybe, maybe for a period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those things could lead to—and we’ve, we’ve modeled that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Other people have too.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve—and what we see is relatively modest increases in inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So—but those are not permanent things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, what’ll, what’ll happen is—the supply side—the supply side in the United States is very dynamic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: People start businesses, they, they reopen restaurants, you know, the airlines are, will be flying again, all of those things will happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so it’ll turn out to be a one—a one-time sort of bulge in, in prices, but it won’t change inflation going forward, because inflation expectations are strongly anchored around 2 percent.
